thread.title: The sheep who thinks he is a DOG: Meet the adorable lamb who curls up with his canine pals
thread.title_full: The sheep who thinks he is a DOG: Meet the adorable lamb who curls up with his canine pals

title: The sheep who thinks he is a DOG: Meet the adorable lamb who curls up with his canine pals
text:
Nature The sheep who thinks he is a DOG: Meet the adorable lamb who curls up with his canine pals The sheep who thinks he is a DOG: Meet the adorable lamb who curls up with his canine pals THIS adorable little lamb acts more like a dog than a sheep - curling up on the sofa with its canine pals or following owner Emma Childs around. PUBLISHED: 14:45, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 | UPDATED: 15:07, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 BPNS Mrs Childs took Barry the lamb into her home in Fordingbridge, Hampshire, last month 
Mrs Childs took Barry the lamb into her home in Fordingbridge, Hampshire, last month so she could bottle-feed him round the clock after his mum rejected him as a newborn. 
Barry, now four weeks old, is a rare Valais Blacknose, a breed that was only introduced to the UK from Switzerland in 2014. 
The youngster loves nothing more than curling up in a dog basket by the Aga to keep warm and has clearly learnt to copy Mrs Childs' six dogs - jumping up on the sofa for a cuddle. Related articles Dog owners seen as 'more ATTRACTIVE' than those who own cats 
Luckily, Mrs Childs had just left her job as an office manager to manage the flock full-time the day before Barry was born, which meant she was able to look after him round the clock. 
She is now trying to slowly integrate Barry with the rest of the flock so he can be a normal ram. 
While he is willing to spend time with his woolly counterparts, the young lamb won't eat hard food from the trough unless Mrs Childs stays next to him. BPNS Barry is a rare Valais Blacknose 
He comes when she calls his name and still heads into the house for his six bottles a day. He would quite happily snuggle up by the Aga all day Emma Childs 
But he has been accepted by the other lambs and Mrs Childs has already found a home for him to go to once he is fully weaned in about seven weeks' time. 
Mrs Childs, 52, said: “Barry is an incredible character. He's just like a dog. 
“From day one he's been around the dogs so he's completely at home with them. He would quite happily snuggle up by the Aga all day Emma Childs 
“He's very loving and he will jump up on the sofa and sit on my lap. 
“He knows his name, follows me everywhere like a dog and comes when I call him. 
“He is lovely natured and exceedingly tame. 
“He was rejected by his mum, which is quite unusual for the breed. She has had lambs before, there's no rhyme or reason to it. BNPS Emma Childs (right) and business partner Abby Bolt relax with Barry and the dogs on the sofa 
“I tried to get her to accept him but she wasn't having it so I had no option but to step in. 
“He's been an inside lamb ever since. He's very special. 
“My husband Scott has been brilliant about it. All our dogs are rescue dogs so he knows what I'm like and he didn't bat an eyelid when I brought Barry in. 
“When he was first born I was bottle feeding him round the clock every three hours, through the night as well. He was quite small and weak. 
“At night he would go in a dog cage in front of the Aga and during the day he would either sit in a dog bed or follow me round. Man lives with wild animals Tue, February 23, 2016
